title: 107_s1572
content: The Act may be cited as the "Freedom Consolidation Act of 2001". Congress finds that full and active participants in the Partnership for Peace should be invited to become full NATO members in accordance with Article 10 of the NATO Treaty. In 1996, Congress called for the prompt admission of Poland, Hungary, the Czech Republic, and Slovenia to NATO, and emphasized the importance of including emerging democracies in Central and Eastern Europe in the enlargement process. In 1996, Congress called for the prompt admission of Poland, Hungary, the Czech Republic, and Slovenia to NATO, emphasizing the importance of including emerging democracies in Central and Eastern Europe in the enlargement process. The European Security Act of 1998 further stated that Romania, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, and Bulgaria would also make outstanding contributions to NATO's goals and enhance stability, freedom, and peace in Europe. At the Madrid Summit of the NATO Alliance in July 1997, Poland, Hungary, and the Czech Republic were invited to join the Alliance in the first round of NATO enlargement, with the expectation of extending further invitations to nations willing and able to contribute to NATO's goals in the future. At the Washington Summit of the NATO Alliance in April 1999, it was declared that NATO will continue to welcome new members who can fulfill the objectives of the Treaty and contribute to peace. The Alliance expects to extend further invitations to nations willing and able to assume membership responsibilities. In late 2002, NATO will hold a summit in Prague, Czech Republic, to decide on inviting additional emerging democracies in Central and Eastern Europe to join the Alliance in the next round of NATO enlargement. In May 2000 in Vilnius, Lithuania, emerging democracies in Central and Eastern Europe declared their cooperation in seeking NATO membership in the next round of enlargement. President George W. Bush expressed support for NATO membership for all emerging democracies in Central and Eastern Europe during a speech in Warsaw, Poland in June 2001. President George W. Bush expressed support for NATO membership for all emerging democracies in Central and Eastern Europe during a speech in Warsaw, Poland in June 2001. He emphasized the importance of not using nations as pawns and stated that NATO's doors should remain open for new members. Former President William J. Clinton also echoed similar sentiments in a speech in Detroit, Michigan in October 1996, emphasizing the need to advance the cause of freedom and not repeat past mistakes like Munich and Yalta. Former President William J. Clinton emphasized NATO's openness to all emerging democracies in Europe, stating that no nation will be automatically excluded and no country outside NATO will have a veto. He also highlighted the importance of preventing a gray zone of insecurity in Europe. SEC. 3. DECLARATIONS OF POLICY. Congress reaffirms its support for the continued enlargement of the NATO Alliance as expressed in various acts and declarations, including those by President George W. Bush and former President William J. Clinton. Congress reaffirms support for NATO enlargement as articulated by Presidents George W. Bush and William J. Clinton, urging NATO allies to work with the United States towards this vision at the Prague Summit in 2002. Designation of Slovakia to receive assistance under the NATO Participation Act of 1994. Slovakia is designated as eligible to receive assistance under the NATO Participation Act of 1994, in addition to other countries like Poland, Hungary, the Czech Republic, and Slovenia. The Czech Republic, Slovenia, Romania, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, and Bulgaria are designated as eligible to receive assistance under NATO Enlargement Facilitation Act of 1996 and European Security Act of 1998. This does not preclude the President from designating other countries for assistance under the NATO Participation Act of 1994. The President can designate other emerging democracies in Central and Eastern Europe as eligible to receive assistance under the NATO Participation Act of 1994. SEC. 5. Authorization of security assistance for countries designated under the NATO Participation Act of 1994. Authorization of Foreign Military Financing for fiscal year 2002 under the Arms Export Control Act includes grants for Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, Slovakia, and Slovenia. In fiscal year 2002, grants for Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, Slovakia, Slovenia, Bulgaria, and Romania are authorized under the Arms Export Control Act. Amendments are made to section 515 of the Security Assistance Act of 2000.
